description:
Autographa pulchrina, commonly known as the Beautiful Golden Y or Golden Y, is a species of moth belonging to the family Noctuidae. It is a medium-sized moth with a wingspan of approximately 35-45 millimeters.

The forewings of Autographa pulchrina are typically golden-brown in color, with distinct silvery-white markings that form a distinctive "Y" or "golden Y" shape near the center of the wing. The hindwings are typically pale grey or white in color.

The larvae, or caterpillars, of Autographa pulchrina are typically green in color, with a distinctive pattern of white or yellowish stripes along the body. They feed on a variety of herbaceous plants, including various species of plants in the Fabaceae (legume) family.

Autographa pulchrina is widely distributed across Europe and Asia, and can be found in a variety of habitats, including grasslands, meadows, and deciduous forests. The species is known to have multiple generations per year, with adults typically flying from late spring through the summer months.
